channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target in Ukraine.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin knows that Ukraine’s fate, its access to the sea and its grain exports hinge on Odesa. Without it, the country shrivels to a landlocked rump state.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:description: Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.

item.title: A Famous Walrus Is Killed, and Norwegians Are Divided
item.description: The killing of Freya has polarized Oslo and threatens to blight the image of a country more commonly associated with diplomatic good deeds than mob-like hits.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Tor Erik Schrder/NTB, Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Freya resting on a boat in Frognerkilen, on the Oslofjord in Norway, last month.

item.title: U.S. Is Sending More Weapons to Ukraine, This Time to Aid Counterattack
item.description: The newly announced U.S. shipment of weaponry includes armored vehicles that can clear minefields ahead of major ground movements. Russia said it foiled Ukraine’s attempts this week to strike Crimea.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman retrieving items from a home damaged this week by a rocket strike in Druzhkivka, Ukraine, in the Donetsk region.

item.title: For Former Rebel in West Africa, Her Allegiance Still Lies With Russia
item.description: The Kremlin armed a generation of freedom fighters in Africa, like Joana Gomes, who helped Guinea-Bissau win liberation. So her decision to take Moscow’s side in its war with Ukraine was never in doubt.
item.dc:creator: Ricci Shryock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Ricci Shryock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Gomes at her home in Bissau, the capital. As a lawmaker, she has focused on improving Guinea-Bissau’s health care system.

item.title: Europeans Debate Barring Russian Tourists Over the Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: A proposed visa ban has divided many Europeans, with some arguing it would increase pressure inside Russia and others questioning whether it plays into Kremlin claims of persecution by the West.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: The Nuijamaa border crossing in Finland, which has received a relatively large number of Russians since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: How Democracy Is Under Threat Across the Globe
item.description: The United States is far from alone in facing pressure on its democratic norms and institutions.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: A supporter of the presidential candidate Raila Odinga in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday. A razor-thin election this month has brought with it another test for the African country’s democracy.

item.title: Heat and Drought in Europe Strain Energy Supply
item.description: The dry summer has reduced hydropower in Norway, threatened nuclear reactors in France and crimped coal transport in Germany. And that’s on top of Russian gas cuts.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sverre Eikeland, chief operating officer of a hydroelectric producer, indicating the previous water line at the Skjerkevatn Reservoir in Aseral, Norway.

item.title: Drink More Alcohol, Japan Tells Young People
item.description: The country’s tax agency, hoping to reverse the alcohol industry’s pandemic doldrums, is holding a contest to encourage more drinking among the young.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and John Yoon
item.media:description: An izakaya in Tokyo in June.

item.title: The Bloody Uprising Against the Taliban Led by One of Their Own
item.description: In northern Afghanistan, hundreds of Shiite Muslims joined an uprising led by a former Taliban commander. Times journalists spent time with the rebels massed to defend themselves.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Najim Rahim and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mawlawi Mahdi Mujahid.

item.title: ‘I Have Nothing Left’: Flooding Adds to Afghanistan’s Crises
item.description: Widespread flash floods have left more than 40 dead and 100 others injured in recent days, battering a country already reeling from an economic crisis, terrorist attacks and other natural disasters.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary, Christina Goldbaum and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Mexico Says 43 Students’ Disappearance Was a State Crime
item.description: The authorities said for the first time that the state had been a key player in the likely massacre of students from a teachers’ college in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Celia Talbot Tobin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to the 43 disappeared students in Mexico City in 2019.

item.title: China’s Heat Wave Strains Its Economy
item.description: A severe drought has dented energy supplies and disrupted access to water for hundreds of thousands. Cities order rolling blackouts; farmers rush to save crops.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Joy Dong
item.media:description: In Wuhan last week, the heat had people seeking the cool of a river swim.

item.title: Fast-Spreading Wildfires Kill at Least 37 People in Algeria
item.description: The government blamed extreme heat and strong winds. Heat waves in the North African nation, about 80 percent of which is covered by the Sahara, are expected to increase in frequency and severity.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Massinissa Benlakehal
item.media:description: A burned bus left by wildfires in northeast Algeria on Thursday.

item.title: Party Videos of Sanna Marin, Finland’s Prime Minister, Draw Criticism
item.description: Criticism of the leader, Sanna Marin, 36, over parties she’s attended showed the difficulties of keeping life private in the age of cellphones and social media.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:credit: Matias Honkamaa/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland in the city of Kuopio on Thursday.

item.title: In India, 11 Convicted of Rape and Murder in Bilkis Bano Case Walk Free
item.description: Just as Bilkis Bano had started to rebuild her life after grisly communal violence in 2002, a state government cut short her assailants’ life sentences.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh, Suhasini Raj and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The jail where the convicts in the Bilkis Bano rape case were imprisoned in Godhra, India.

item.title: Germany’s Stony-Faced Chancellor Faces Critics on Nearly Every Side
item.description: After eight months in office, Olaf Scholz is still struggling to find his footing, drawing questions over a tax scandal and criticism of his response to a Holocaust remark made at his side.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz speaking Friday at the town hall in Hamburg, where he was summoned to testify in a tax scandal.

item.title: Ukrainian Strikes May Be Slowing Russia’s Advance
item.description: A new strategy of attacks on logistical targets in Russian-held territory is having an impact, analysts say, symbolically as well as militarily.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military recruitment posters on Friday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: How Raila Odinga Lost His Stronghold, Then Kenya’s Presidency
item.description: In his fifth, and possibly last, bid for president, Raila Odinga failed to enthuse a crucial bloc of voters in his own backyard that would have catapulted him to the top job.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Candidates like Sospeter Obungu Owich ran as independent candidates after they were pushed aside by Mr. Odinga’s party.

item.title: Dmitri Vrubel, Who Planted a Kiss on the Berlin Wall, Dies at 62
item.description: A Russian-born painter, he created a mural of the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev smooching the East German leader Erich Honecker — and with it a tourist attraction.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Mr. Vrubel beside his Berlin Wall mural in 2009. It took on a life of its own, becoming a symbol of Communist decay and an emblem of a freewheeling, artistic Berlin, replicated on T-shirts, mugs and postcards.

item.title: Russia’s Gazprom Announces Another Halt to Germany’s Gas Flow
item.description: A three-day shutdown of the Nord Stream pipeline, which the company attributed to repairs, is likely to cause jitters in Europe’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A section of the Nord Stream pipeline at the port of Lubmin, Germany, last year.

item.title: TikTok Browser Can Track Users’ Keystrokes, According to New Research
item.description: In the web browser used within the TikTok app, supplementary code lets the company track every character typed by users. The company said the capability was for troubleshooting.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Ryan Mac and Chang Che
item.media:description: TikTok, the Chinese-owned app, has faced scrutiny in Washington over its data practices.

item.title: Nafis Sadik, U.N. Official and ‘Proud Champion of Choice,’ Dies at 92
item.description: An obstetrician, she led a groundbreaking effort to put women’s rights to control all aspects of their lives at the heart of the global population debate.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan

item.title: Putin Makes Public Remarks on Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant As Tensions Mount
item.description: The remarks came during a telephone call initiated by President Emmanuel Macron of France.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a news conference in Tehran in July. On Friday, he accused the Ukrainian military of risking a “large-scale catastrophe” in the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.

item.title: 1972: Greece Grants Political Asylum to 6 Russian Sailors
item.description: The men asked for asylum after their trawler sailed into a bay near Piraeus harbor.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: How is Russia’s War in Ukraine Going?
item.description: We explain why the last several weeks of the war in Ukraine have gone poorly for Russia.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit last week.

item.title: A bridge to Crimea is a vital Russian link, and a potential Ukrainian target.
item.description: After overnight blasts into Friday, the Kerch Strait bridge appeared undamaged.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The road-and-rail bridge over the Kerch Strait was built to connect Russia with the Crimean Peninsula.

item.title: China’s Covid Lockdowns Strand Tourists
item.description: Tens of thousands of domestic travelers were stuck at their summer vacation destinations after local outbreaks forced them into quarantine.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: Tourists this month at the airport in Sanya on Hainan Island in China. After a recent outbreak, the local government suspended public transportation and halted sales of rail tickets as part of a citywide lockdown.

item.title: Could New Zealand Change Its Name?
item.description: A petition before Parliament asks that the country be called “Aotearoa,” which loosely translates from Maori as the “land of the long white cloud.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wellington and the Miramar Peninsula, in New Zealand. A petition seeks to make it officially Aotearoa and restore other places’ original Maori names.

item.title: U.N. Chief Visits Odesa, Facing Limits of Influence Over War in Ukraine
item.description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, witnessed grain shipments, one of his organization’s most concrete achievements.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Dan Bilefsky and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Firefighters spraying remnants of a wildfire near Belin-Beliet, in southwestern France, last Saturday.

item.title: Remains of 2 Children Are Found in Suitcases Bought at New Zealand Auction
item.description: The police did not immediately release the precise ages of the children, their genders, or whether they might have been related. “We still have a lot of unanswered questions,” a detective said.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Dean Purcell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police investigators in Auckland, New Zealand, on Aug. 11, after human remains were discovered in suitcases.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Accuse Each Other of Plotting Attack on Nuclear Plant
item.description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the largest in Europe, has already been hit by shelling, and the United Nations chief, warning of disaster, called for a demilitarized zone around it.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency rescue teams, wearing suits to protect against radiation, practicing a nuclear disaster drill on Wednesday in the city of Zaporizhzhia.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Heat Shakes China’s Economy
item.description: Plus the U.S. and Taiwan will begin formal trade talks and Cambodia spars with the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Nets covering tea plantations to protect them from the sun in Hangzhou.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine trade accusations of a potential attack on a nuclear complex, terrifying its workers.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daily shelling at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex has sparked international concerns about the possibility of a meltdown or release of radiation from spent nuclear fuel in storage.

item.title: Polio Was Almost Eradicated. This Year It Staged a Comeback.
item.description: Before its discovery in New York’s wastewater, the virus made a series of ominous appearances around the world.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Thoko Chikondi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charles Bizimaki administered a polio vaccine at the Makhwira Health Center in southern Malawi, after the country recorded its first polio case in 30 years.

item.title: Scientists Boost Soy Crops Through Improved Photosynthesis
item.description: Researchers increased yield in soy plants by making them better at photosynthesis, the process that powers life. The findings hold promise for feeding a warming world.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:description: Improved crop yields could particularly benefit poorer parts of the world. A soybean harvest near Campos Lindos, Brazil.

item.title: Estonia Says It Repelled Major Russian Cyberattack
item.description: The hacking group, Killnet, said the attack was in retaliation for Estonia’s removal of a Soviet tank from a World War II memorial.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Estonia’s removal of a Soviet-era tank that had stood at a war memorial on its border with Russia may have sparked the biggest wave of cyberattacks on Estonia in more than a decade.

item.title: As Soaring Prices Roil Britain, Its Leader Vacations and a Likely Successor Sidesteps the Issue
item.description: Britain is facing multiple economic shocks, from soaring energy prices to the hollowing out of the labor market by Brexit. But these issues seem disconnected from the fight to replace Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Shoppers at a supermarket in London in June. Residents of Britain have seen energy and food prices shoot up.

item.title: Palestinian Rights Groups Raided by Israeli Soldiers
item.description: The offices of seven groups were shuttered, months after Israel designated six of them as terrorist organizations. The groups said the moves were meant to silence criticism.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
item.media:description: The offices of the Union of Palestinian Women’s Committees in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday. The group was one of seven targeted by Israeli soldiers.

item.title: U.S. Ship Sunk by Germans in 1917 Is Found Off English Coast
item.description: The ship, the U.S.S. Jacob Jones, was the first U.S. destroyer to be lost to enemy action. It had been missing for more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: U.S. Naval History and Heritage Command
item.media:description: Jacob Jones (Destroyer # 61) underway in 1916 soon after she was completed.

item.title: U.K. Train Strikes Bring More Summer Disruptions
item.description: Travelers resigned themselves to additional days of struggles as workers seeking higher pay walked out, a day after Britain reported its highest inflation rate in decades.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A deserted platform at Euston train station in London on Thursday, when strikes largely brought train travel to a standstill in Britain.

item.title: Bucha Is Still Burying Victims of Wartime Atrocities
item.description: More bodies were interred in the Kyiv suburb this week. They had no names, only numbers.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twenty-one unidentified bodies were laid to rest in a mass burial conducted by the Rev. Andrii Halavin, a priest in Bucha, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Global inflation woes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Shopping in central London on Wednesday.

item.title: Sleepy Greek Port Becomes U.S. Arms Hub, as Ukraine War Reshapes Region
item.description: The flow of U.S. military supplies through Alexandroupoli has angered Russia and Turkey. Now, firms with ties to Russia and America are competing for control of the port.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local officials said they hoped the military upgrades at the port would attract investments in other industries.

item.title: Taiwan and U.S. to Begin Formal Trade Talks
item.description: The announcement comes amid tensions with China over the self-governing island, which several American lawmakers recently visited.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Street stalls in Taipei, Taiwan. Despite the island’s small size, it is the United States’ eighth-largest trading partner.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Liz Cheney, Out
item.description: Plus a mortgage strike in China and resistance fighters in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: In her concession speech, Liz Cheney noted that her dedication to the party has its limits: “I love my country more.”

item.title: Hard-hit Kharkiv is rocked by more blasts.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A residential hall hit by a rocket in the Saltivka neighborhood of Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Spanish Court Clears Way to Return Body of Angola’s Ex-President
item.description: After José Eduardo dos Santos died in Spain, the decision on where to bury him pitted his widow and the Angolan government against some of his adult children.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista, Gilberto Neto and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: José Eduardo dos Santos, the former president of Angola, died in Spain last month, triggering a family feud over repatriating his body.

item.title: Britons Brace for More Hardship as Prices Soar Amid Inflation
item.description: Cutting back on meat. Choosing cheaper supermarket brands. Stockpiling soap. Soaring prices force more sacrifices.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Euan Ward
item.media:description: A supermarket in London in June. In Britain, inflation rose 10.1 percent in July compared to a year earlier, with consumer prices growing at their fastest pace since 1982.

item.title: Top Vatican Official Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct in Quebec
item.description: A woman accused Cardinal Marc Ouellet, a member of Pope Francis’ inner circle, of inappropriately touching and kissing her.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Cardinal Marc Ouellet, the former archbishop of Quebec, was named in a lawsuit made public this week.

item.title: Inflation Hits the British Breakfast Table With Rising Food Prices
item.description: From bread to butter to baked beans, a survey of typical breakfast items makes clear that there’s no relief from rising inflation for Britons when they sit down for their morning meal.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Consumer prices in Britain rose 10.1 percent in July from the previous year.

item.title: Palestinian Leader Accused Israel of ‘50 Holocausts,’ Causing an Uproar
item.description: Facing international condemnation, the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, later walked back the remarks he had made at a news conference in Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, speaking on Tuesday during a news conference in Berlin, where he made comments that were roundly criticized.

item.title: In England, Ukrainian Recruits Are Training for Frontline Battles
item.description: British military trainers are teaching essential battlefield skills to recruits heading into the fight back home.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: The training in England seeks to teach essential skills to Ukrainian recruits.

item.title: E.U.’s Monkeypox Response Leads to Pandemic Flashbacks
item.description: After Covid disparities sent people across borders in search of vaccines, the European Union tried to create a level playing field. But it’s still far from complete.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Rebecca Marshall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flavio Stupino in the bathroom of a rental apartment in Nice, France, on Tuesday. Mr. Stupino, a bank worker in Milan, crossed the border from Italy to get a monkeypox vaccine.

item.title: Israel and Turkey to Restore Full Diplomatic Ties
item.description: A four-year chill in relations has thawed in recent months, and the two nations, once close regional allies, will now exchange ambassadors again.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The meeting in March of President Isaac Herzog of Israel, left, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey was a sign of their countries’ efforts to reset fractured relations.

item.title: Ukraine’s top commander says fighting at the front is ‘intense but fully controlled.’
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers along the front line in Mykolaiv last week.

item.title: The Party of Trump
item.description: A look at the latest results from last night’s primaries, and their larger meaning for the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liz Cheney’s concession speech in Jackson, Wyo.

item.title: North Korea Launches Two Missiles in First Test Since June
item.description: The test came as South Korea was gearing up for joint military drills with the United States and offered economic assistance to the North.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: South Korea’s president, Yoon Suk-yeol, at a news conference on Wednesday. Urging North Korea to take steps to end its nuclear program, he pledged diplomatic and economic support.
